analyzed: sa nimitta vagga
translated: The Chapter about Signs

original: “Sanimittā, bhikkhave, uppajjanti pāpakā akusalā dhammā, no animittā.
analyzed: sa nimittāḥ bhikkhave uppajjanti pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ no animittāḥ
translated: “Bad unwholesome qualities arise with a sign, not without a sign.

original: Tasseva nimittassa pahānā evaṁ te pāpakā akusalā dhammā na hontī”ti.
analyzed: tassa iva nimittassa pahānā evam te pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ na honti iti
translated: With the abandoning of that sign, those bad unwholesome qualities don’t exist.”

original: “Sanidānā, bhikkhave, uppajjanti pāpakā akusalā dhammā, no anidānā.
analyzed: sa nidānāḥ bhikkhave uppajjanti pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ no a nidānāḥ
translated: “Bad unwholesome qualities arise with a source, not without a source.

original: Tasseva nidānassa pahānā evaṁ te pāpakā akusalā dhammā na hontī”ti.
analyzed: tassa iva nidānassa pahānā evam te pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ na honti iti
translated: With the abandoning of that source, those bad unwholesome qualities don’t exist.”

original: “Sahetukā, bhikkhave, uppajjanti pāpakā akusalā dhammā, no ahetukā.
analyzed: sa hetukāḥ bhikkhave uppajjanti pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ no ahetukāḥ
translated: “Bad unwholesome qualities arise with a cause, not without a cause.

original: Tasseva hetussa pahānā evaṁ te pāpakā akusalā dhammā na hontī”ti.
analyzed: tassa iva hetussa pahānā evam te pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ na honti iti
translated: With the abandoning of that cause, those bad unwholesome qualities don’t exist.”

original: “Sasaṅkhārā, bhikkhave, uppajjanti pāpakā akusalā dhammā, no asaṅkhārā.
analyzed: sa saṅkhārāḥ bhikkhave uppajjanti pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ no asaṅkhārāḥ
translated: “Bad, unwholesome qualities arise with volitional formations, not without volitional formations.

original: Tesaṁyeva saṅkhārānaṁ pahānā evaṁ te pāpakā akusalā dhammā na hontī”ti.
analyzed: tesayā iva saṅkhārānam pahānā evam te pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ na honti iti
translated: With the abandoning of those very volitional formations, those bad, unwholesome qualities do not exist.”

original: “Sappaccayā, bhikkhave, uppajjanti pāpakā akusalā dhammā, no appaccayā.
analyzed: sa paccayāḥ bhikkhave uppajjanti pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ no appaccayāḥ
translated: “Bad, unwholesome qualities arise with a condition, not without a condition.

original: Tasseva paccayassa pahānā evaṁ te pāpakā akusalā dhammā na hontī”ti.
analyzed: tassa iva paccayassa pahānā evam te pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ na honti iti
translated: With the abandoning of that very condition, those bad, unwholesome qualities do not exist.”

original: “Sarūpā, bhikkhave, uppajjanti pāpakā akusalā dhammā, no arūpā.
analyzed: sarūpāḥ bhikkhave uppajjanti pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ no arūpā
translated: “Bad, unwholesome qualities arise with form, not without form.

original: Tasseva rūpassa pahānā evaṁ te pāpakā akusalā dhammā na hontī”ti.
analyzed: tassa eva rūpassa pahānā evam te pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ na honti iti
translated: With the abandoning of that very form, those bad, unwholesome qualities do not exist.”

original: “Savedanā, bhikkhave, uppajjanti pāpakā akusalā dhammā, no avedanā.
analyzed: sa vedanāḥ bhikkhave uppajjanti pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ no a vedanā
translated: “Bad, unwholesome qualities arise with feeling, not without feeling.

original: Tassāyeva vedanāya pahānā evaṁ te pāpakā akusalā dhammā na hontī”ti.
analyzed: tassāya iva vedanāya pahānā evam te pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ na honti iti
translated: With the abandoning of that very feeling, those bad, unwholesome qualities do not exist.”

original: “Sasaññā, bhikkhave, uppajjanti pāpakā akusalā dhammā, no asaññā.
analyzed: sa saññāḥ bhikkhave uppajjanti pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ no asaññā
translated: “Bad, unwholesome qualities arise with perception, not without perception.

original: Tassāyeva saññāya pahānā evaṁ te pāpakā akusalā dhammā na hontī”ti.
analyzed: tassāya iva saññāya pahānā evam te pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ na honti iti
translated: With the abandoning of that very perception, those bad, unwholesome qualities do not exist.”

original: “Saviññāṇā, bhikkhave, uppajjanti pāpakā akusalā dhammā, no aviññāṇā.
analyzed: sa viññāṇāḥ bhikkhave uppajjanti pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ no aviññāṇā
translated: “Bad, unwholesome qualities arise with consciousness, not without consciousness.

original: Tasseva viññāṇassa pahānā evaṁ te pāpakā akusalā dhammā na hontī”ti.
analyzed: tassa iva viññāṇassa pahānā evam te pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ na honti iti
translated: With the abandoning of that very consciousness, these bad, unwholesome qualities don’t exist.”

original: “Saṅkhatārammaṇā, bhikkhave, uppajjanti pāpakā akusalā dhammā, no asaṅkhatārammaṇā.
analyzed: saṅkhata ārammaṇāḥ bhikkhave uppajjanti pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ no asaṅkhata ārammaṇāḥ
translated: “Bad, unwholesome qualities arise with a conditioned object, not without a conditioned object.

original: Tasseva saṅkhatassa pahānā evaṁ te pāpakā akusalā dhammā na hontī”ti.
analyzed: tassa iva saṅkhatassa pahānā evam te pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ na honti iti
translated: With the abandoning of that very conditioned object, these bad, unwholesome qualities don’t exist.”

analyzed: āyācana vagga
translated: The Chapter on Begging

original: “Saddho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṁ sammā āyācamāno āyāceyya:
analyzed: saddhaḥ bhikkhave bhikkhu evam sammā āyācamānaḥ āyāceyya
translated: “Monks, a faithful monk who is practicing accordingly should beg his robe-cloth, thinking,

analyzed: tādisaḥ homi yādisā sāriputtama uggallānāti
translated: ‘May I be like Sāriputta and Moggallāna.’

original: Esā, bhikkhave, tulā etaṁ pamāṇaṁ mama sāvakānaṁ bhikkhūnaṁ yadidaṁ sāriputtamoggallānā”ti.
analyzed: esā bhikkhave tulā etam pamāṇam mama sāvakānam bhikkhūnam yat idam sāriputta moggallānā ati
translated: This is the standard, the reference point for my monk disciples—namely, Sāriputta and Moggallāna.”

original: “Saddhā, bhikkhave, bhikkhunī evaṁ sammā āyācamānā āyāceyya:
analyzed: saddhā bhikkhave bhikkhunī evam sammā āyācamānā āyāceyya
translated: “Monks, a faithful nun who is practicing accordingly should beg her robe-cloth, thinking,

original: ‘tādisī homi yādisī khemā ca bhikkhunī uppalavaṇṇā cā’ti.
analyzed: tādisī homi yādisī khemā ca bhikkhunī uppala vaṇṇā ca ati
translated: ‘May I be like the nuns Khemā and Uppalavaṇṇā.’

original: Esā, bhikkhave, tulā etaṁ pamāṇaṁ mama sāvikānaṁ bhikkhunīnaṁ yadidaṁ khemā ca bhikkhunī uppalavaṇṇā cā”ti.
analyzed: esā bhikkhave tulā etam pamāṇam mama sāvikānam bhikkhunīnam yat idam khemā ca bhikkhunī uppala vaṇṇā ca ati
translated: This is the standard, the reference point for my nun disciples—namely, the nuns Khemā and Uppalavaṇṇā.”

original: “Saddho, bhikkhave, upāsako evaṁ sammā āyācamāno āyāceyya:
analyzed: saddhaḥ bhikkhave upāsakaḥ evam sammā āyācamānaḥ āyāceyya
translated: “A faithful male lay follower who is making a proper effort might wish:

original: ‘tādiso homi yādiso citto ca gahapati hatthako ca āḷavako’ti.
analyzed: tādisaḥ homi yādiso citto ca gahapati hatthako ca āḷavako ti
translated: ‘If only I could be like Citta the householder and Hatthaka of Āḷavī!’

original: Esā, bhikkhave, tulā etaṁ pamāṇaṁ mama sāvakānaṁ upāsakānaṁ yadidaṁ citto ca gahapati hatthako ca āḷavako”ti.
analyzed: esā bhikkhave tulā etam pamāṇam mama sāvakānam upāsakānam yat idam citto ca gahapati hatthako ca āḷavako ti
translated: Citta the householder and Hatthaka of Āḷavī are the standard and measure.

original: “Saddhā, bhikkhave, upāsikā evaṁ sammā āyācamānā āyāceyya:
analyzed: saddhā bhikkhave upāsikā evam sammā āyācamānā āyāceyya
translated: “A faithful female lay follower who is making a proper effort might wish:

original: ‘tādisī homi yādisī khujjuttarā ca upāsikā veḷukaṇḍakiyā ca nandamātā’ti.
analyzed: tādisī homi yādisī khujjuttarā ca upāsikā veḷukaṇḍakiyā ca nandamātā ati
translated: ‘If only I could be like the lay followers Khujjuttarā and Veḷukaṇṭakī Nandamātā!’

original: Esā, bhikkhave, tulā etaṁ pamāṇaṁ mama sāvikānaṁ upāsikānaṁ yadidaṁ khujjuttarā ca upāsikā veḷukaṇḍakiyā ca nandamātā”ti.
analyzed: esā bhikkhave tulā etam pamāṇam mama sāvikānam upāsikānam yat idam khujjuttarā ca upāsikā veḷukaṇḍakiyā ca nandamātā ati
translated: The lay followers Khujjuttarā and Veḷukaṇṭakī Nandamātā are the standard and measure.

original: “Dvīhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bālo abyatto asappuriso khataṁ upahataṁ attānaṁ pariharati, sāvajjo ca hoti sānuvajjo ca viññūnaṁ, bahuñca apuññaṁ pasavati.
analyzed: dvīhi bhikkhave dhammehi samannāgataḥ bālaḥ abyattaḥ asappurisaḥ khatam upahatam attānam pariharati sa āvajjaḥ ca hoti sa anuvajjaḥ ca viññūna bahuñca apuññam pasavati
translated: “Monks, a foolish, incompetent, unskillful person—one who is not an arahant but claims to be—who possesses two qualities covers up his own faults, and he does so in two ways. He is reproached and criticized by the wise, and he makes much bad karma.

analyzed: katamehi dvīhi
translated: What two qualities?

analyzed: an anuvicca a pariyogāhetvā a vaṇṇa a rahassa vaṇṇam bhāsati
translated: Without making inquiries or examining, he praises those who are unpraiseworthy.

analyzed: an anuvicca a pariyogāhetvā vaṇṇā rahassa avaṇṇam bhāsati
translated: Without making inquiries or examining, he criticizes those who are praiseworthy.

original: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, dvīhi dhammehi samannāgato bālo abyatto asappuriso khataṁ upahataṁ attānaṁ pariharati, sāvajjo ca hoti sānuvajjo ca viññūnaṁ, bahuñca apuññaṁ pasavatīti.
analyzed: imehi kho bhikkhave dvīhi dhammehi samannāgataḥ bālaḥ abyattaḥ asappuriso khatam upahatam attānam pariharati sa āvajjaḥ ca hoti sa anuvajjaḥ ca viññūna bahuñca apuññam pasavati iti
translated: When a fool possesses these two qualities, he destroys himself and doesn’t attain any distinction. He’s blamed and criticized by sensible people, and he makes much bad karma.

original: Dvīhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato paṇḍito viyatto sappuriso akkhataṁ anupahataṁ attānaṁ pariharati, anavajjo ca hoti ananuvajjo ca viññūnaṁ, bahuñca puññaṁ pasavati.
analyzed: dvīhi bhikkhave dhammehi samannāgataḥ paṇḍitaḥ viyattaḥ sappurisaḥ akkhatam an upahatam attānam pariharati anavajjaḥ ca hoti ananuvajjaḥ ca viññūna bahuñca puññam pasavati
translated: When a wise person possesses two qualities, he doesn’t destroy himself and attains distinction. He’s not blamed or criticized by sensible people, and he makes much merit.

original: Katamehi dvīhi?🔽Anuvicca pariyogāhetvā avaṇṇārahassa avaṇṇaṁ bhāsati,
analyzed: katamehi dvīhi  anuvicca pariyogāhetvā avaṇṇā rahassa avaṇṇam bhāsati
translated: What are the two?🔽After making inquiries and examining, he criticizes those who are unpraiseworthy.

analyzed: anuvicca pariyogāhetvā vaṇṇā rahassa vaṇṇam bhāsati
translated: After making inquiries and examining, he praises those who are praiseworthy.

original: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, dvīhi dhammehi samannāgato paṇḍito viyatto sappuriso akkhataṁ
analyzed: imehi kho bhikkhave dvīhi dhammehi samannāgataḥ paṇḍitaḥ viyattaḥ sappurisaḥ
translated: When a wise person possesses these two qualities, he doesn’t destroy himself and attains distinction.

original: anupahataṁ attānaṁ pariharati, anavajjo ca hoti ananuvajjo ca viññūnaṁ, bahuñca puññaṁ pasavatī”ti.
analyzed: an upahatam attānam pariharati anavajjaḥ ca hoti ananuvajjaḥ ca viññūna bahuñca puññam pasavati iti
translated: they look after themselves with care, they don’t get blamed and criticized by the observant, and they make much merit.”

original: “Dvīhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bālo abyatto asappuriso khataṁ upahataṁ attānaṁ pariharati, sāvajjo ca hoti sānuvajjo ca viññūnaṁ, bahuñca apuññaṁ pasavati.
analyzed: dvīhi bhikkhave dhammehi samannāgataḥ bālaḥ abyattaḥ asappurisaḥ khatam upahatam attānam pariharati sa āvajjaḥ ca hoti sa anuvajjaḥ ca viññūna bahuñca apuññam pasavati
translated: “When a fool is endowed with two things, he destroys himself, he’s badly off and miserable, he gets blamed and criticized by the observant, and he makes much demerit.

original: Katamehi dvīhi?🔽Ananuvicca apariyogāhetvā appasādanīye ṭhāne pasādaṁ upadaṁseti,
analyzed: katamehi dvīhi  an anuvicca a pariyogāhetvā appasādanīye ṭhāne pasādam upadaseti
translated: With what two?🔽Without examining or scrutinizing, he has confidence in and relies on a person who is not a good friend.

original: ananuvicca apariyogāhetvā pasādanīye ṭhāne appasādaṁ upadaṁseti.
analyzed: an anuvicca a pariyogāhetvā pasādanīye ṭhāne appasādam upadaseti
translated: Without examining or scrutinizing, he doesn’t have confidence in and doesn’t rely on a person who is a good friend.

original: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, dvīhi dhammehi samannāgato bālo abyatto asappuriso khataṁ upahataṁ attānaṁ pariharati, sāvajjo ca hoti sānuvajjo ca viññūnaṁ, bahuñca apuññaṁ pasavatīti.
analyzed: imehi kho bhikkhave dvīhi dhammehi samannāgataḥ bālaḥ abyattaḥ asappuriso khatam upahatam attānam pariharati sa āvajjaḥ ca hoti sa anuvajjaḥ ca viññūna bahuñca apuññam pasavati iti
translated: When a fool is endowed with these two things, he destroys himself, he’s badly off and miserable, he gets blamed and criticized by the observant, and he makes much demerit.”

original: Dvīhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato paṇḍito viyatto sappuriso akkhataṁ anupahataṁ attānaṁ pariharati, anavajjo ca hoti ananuvajjo ca viññūnaṁ, bahuñca puññaṁ pasavati.
analyzed: dvīhi bhikkhave dhammehi samannāgataḥ paṇḍitaḥ viyattaḥ sappurisaḥ akkhatam an upahatam attānam pariharati anavajjaḥ ca hoti ananuvajjaḥ ca viññūna bahuñca puññam pasavati
translated: When a wise, competent, good person possesses two things, they maintain themselves unconfused and unharmed. They’re blameless and above reproach by the observant. And they generate a lot of merit.

original: Katamehi dvīhi?🔽Anuvicca pariyogāhetvā appasādanīye ṭhāne appasādaṁ upadaṁseti,
analyzed: katamehi dvīhi  anuvicca pariyogāhetvā appasādanīye ṭhāne appasādam upadaseti
translated: What two?🔽After examination and enquiry, they place confidence in a place of confidence.

original: anuvicca pariyogāhetvā pasādanīye ṭhāne pasādaṁ upadaṁseti.
analyzed: anuvicca pariyogāhetvā pasādanīye ṭhāne pasādam upadaseti
translated: After examination and enquiry, they don’t place confidence in a place of no confidence.

original: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, dvīhi dhammehi samannāgato paṇḍito viyatto sappuriso akkhataṁ
analyzed: imehi kho bhikkhave dvīhi dhammehi samannāgataḥ paṇḍitaḥ viyattaḥ sappurisaḥ
translated: When a wise, competent, good person possesses these two things, they maintain themselves unconfused and unharmed.

original: anupahataṁ attānaṁ pariharati, anavajjo ca hoti ananuvajjo ca viññūnaṁ, bahuñca puññaṁ pasavatī”ti.
analyzed: an upahatam attānam pariharati anavajjaḥ ca hoti ananuvajjaḥ ca viññūna bahuñca puññam pasavati iti
translated: They’re blameless and above reproach by the observant. And they generate a lot of merit.”

original: “Dvīsu, bhikkhave, micchāpaṭipajjamāno bālo abyatto asappuriso khataṁ upahataṁ attānaṁ pariharati, sāvajjo ca hoti sānuvajjo ca viññūnaṁ, bahuñca apuññaṁ pasavati.
analyzed: dvīsu bhikkhave micchā paṭipajjamānaḥ bālaḥ abyattaḥ asappurisaḥ khatam upahatam attānam pariharati sa avajjaḥ ca hoti sa anuvajjaḥ ca viññūna bahuñca apuññam pasavati
translated: “When a foolish, incompetent, bad person practices two things wrongly, they maintain themselves confused and harmed. They’re blameworthy and subject to reproach by the observant. And they generate a lot of demerit.

analyzed: katamesu dvīsu
translated: What two?

analyzed: mātari ca pitari ca
translated: Mother and father.

original: Imesu kho, bhikkhave, dvīsu micchāpaṭipajjamāno bālo abyatto asappuriso khataṁ upahataṁ attānaṁ pariharati, sāvajjo ca hoti sānuvajjo ca viññūnaṁ, bahuñca apuññaṁ pasavatīti.
analyzed: imesu kho bhikkhave dvīsu micchā paṭipajjamānaḥ bālaḥ abyattaḥ asappurisaḥ khatam upahatam attānam pariharati sa avajjaḥ ca hoti sa anuvajjaḥ ca viññūna bahuñca apuññam pasavati iti
translated: Practicing these two things wrongly, a fool, unskillful, not a true person, goes from death to death, is faulted and blamed by sensible people, and makes much demerit.

original: Dvīsu, bhikkhave, sammāpaṭipajjamāno paṇḍito viyatto sappuriso akkhataṁ anupahataṁ attānaṁ pariharati, anavajjo ca hoti ananuvajjo ca viññūnaṁ, bahuñca puññaṁ pasavati.
analyzed: dvīsu bhikkhave sammā paṭipajjamānaḥ paṇḍitaḥ viyattaḥ sappurisaḥ akkhatam an upahatam attānam pariharati anavajjaḥ ca hoti ananuvajjaḥ ca viññūna bahuñca puññam pasavati
translated: Practicing these two things rightly, a wise person, skillful, a true person, goes from birth to birth, is not faulted or blamed by sensible people, and makes much merit.

analyzed: imesu kho bhikkhave dvīsu sammā paṭipajjamānaḥ paṇḍitaḥ viyattaḥ sappurisaḥ 🔽an upahatam attānam pariharati anavajjaḥ ca hoti ananuvajjaḥ ca viññūna bahuñca puññam pasavati iti
translated: Practicing these two things rightly, a wise person, skillful, a true person, goes from birth to birth,

original: “Dvīsu, bhikkhave, micchāpaṭipajjamāno bālo abyatto asappuriso khataṁ upahataṁ attānaṁ pariharati, sāvajjo ca hoti sānuvajjo ca viññūnaṁ, bahuñca apuññaṁ pasavati.
analyzed: dvīsu bhikkhave micchā paṭipajjamānaḥ bālaḥ abyattaḥ asappurisaḥ khatam upahatam attānam pariharati sa avajjaḥ ca hoti sa anuvajjaḥ ca viññūna bahuñca apuññam pasavati
translated: “When a fool, monks, conducts himself or herself in two ways, he or she is cultivating what is unbeneficial, what is hurtful, and what is detrimental, and he or she is to be censured by the wise. He or she generates much demerit and experiences mental pain and sadness.

translated: In the case of the Tathāgata and in the case of a disciple of the Tathāgata.

original: Imesu kho, bhikkhave, micchāpaṭipajjamāno bālo abyatto asappuriso khataṁ upahataṁ attānaṁ pariharati, sāvajjo ca hoti sānuvajjo ca viññūnaṁ, bahuñca apuññaṁ pasavatīti.
analyzed: imesu kho bhikkhave micchā paṭipajjamānaḥ bālaḥ abyattaḥ asappurisaḥ khatam upahatam attānam pariharati sa avajjaḥ ca hoti sa anuvajjaḥ ca viññūna bahuñca apuññam pasavati iti
translated: When a fool conducts himself or herself in these two ways, he or she is cultivating what is unbeneficial, what is hurtful, and what is detrimental, and he or she is to be censured by the wise. He or she generates much demerit and experiences mental pain and sadness.

original: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, dvīhi dhammehi samannāgato idhekacco kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapajjati”.

translated: When a person has these two qualities, after death, when the body breaks up, they’re reborn in a lower realm, a bad destination, a fallen state, hell.”

analyzed: akkodhena ca anupanāhena ca amakkhena ca apaḷāsena ca anissāya ca amacchariyena ca amāyāya ca a sāṭheyyena ca hiriyā ca ottappena ca

translated: … For the warding off of unskillful qualities.🔽… Out of compassion for the laity.

analyzed: pāpa icchānam bhikkhūnam pakkha upacchedāya appasannānam pasādāya pasannānam bhiyyobhāvāya

translated: … why he laid down the recitation of the Monastic Code … why he laid down the suspension of the Monastic Code … why he laid down the invitation ceremony …🔽… why he laid down the suspension of the invitation ceremony … why he laid down the legal procedure of condemnation … why he laid down the legal procedure of demotion …🔽… why he laid down the legal procedure of banishment … why he laid down the legal procedure of reconciliation … why he laid down the legal procedure of ejection …

translated: “To completely understand sensual desire … to completely abandon it … to completely transcend it … to completely abandon it … to completely transcend it … to give up … to let go … to completely abandon sensual desire, two things should be developed. …🔽“To completely understand ill will … to completely abandon it … to completely transcend it … to completely abandon it … to completely transcend it … to give up … to let go … to completely abandon ill will …🔽to completely understand anger … to completely abandon it … to completely transcend it … to completely abandon it … to completely transcend it … to give up … to let go … to completely abandon anger …

original: “Dosassa …pe… mohassa … kodhassa … upanāhassa … makkhassa … paḷāsassa … issāya …
analyzed: dosassa pe mohassa kodhassa upanāhassa makkhassa paḷāsassa issāya
translated: to completely understand denigration … to completely abandon it … to completely transcend it … to completely abandon it … to completely transcend it … to give up … to let go … to completely abandon denigration …🔽to completely understand insolence … to completely abandon it … to completely transcend it … to completely abandon it … to completely transcend it … to give up … to let go … to completely abandon insolence …🔽to completely understand hypocrisy … to completely abandon it … to completely transcend it … to completely abandon it … to completely transcend it … to give up … to let go … to completely abandon hypocrisy …

analyzed: samathaḥ ca vipassanā ca

original: Pamādassa, bhikkhave, paṭinissaggāya ime dve dhammā bhāvetabbā”ti.
